children.subject: Haven’t actually done it but was considering it as an MSE who ended up switching to EECS. My general sense was that the program was pretty good if you were sure that you wanted to take the specific classes laid out for you by the program - so if the upper division EE courses, physics courses, and the subset of MSE courses interested you, then it could be a good choice. I ended up finding that the program was pretty restrictive in terms of extra classes to take just because it was a joint major, and because you didn’t even get to choose which upper divs to take. I ended up wanting to explore more CS in addition to EE after taking lower divs, so I opted to just switch to EECS instead.

Had a friend do it and he wasn’t too happy because it forces you to do a lot of specific EE and MSE courses.  It doesn’t really give you flexibility and it doesn’t seem to give you enough time to get indepth into either EE or MSE so it may actually put you at a worse position if you do not intend to pursue a PhD. If you want to do CS or the signal processing and ML part of EE definitely don’t do this major. Just switch to EECS. Only do it if you are interested in the materials science part of EE bc you probably won’t have the time to study anything else properly.

history.subject: What is your opinion of the EECS/MSE joint major?
